Expectation1: Attending children's school events and activities
Situation1: Children are about to finish school, and the mother should pick them up
Expectation2: Offer help or support when asked
Situation2: An acquaintance asks for a recommendation on a good restaurant in the area.
Story:
I glanced at the clock on my phone—2:45 p.m. My children would be finishing school in fifteen minutes, and I always tried to be there waiting, waving as they spilled out of the building. It was a small thing, but it mattered to them, and to me. As I gathered my keys, a message popped up from Linda, an acquaintance from the neighborhood. “Hey! Sorry for the last-minute ask, but do you know any good restaurants nearby? My parents are visiting, and I want to take them somewhere nice tonight. Can you help?”

I hesitated, thumb hovering over the screen. Linda had always been kind, and I knew she didn’t have many friends in town. She probably needed a quick answer, maybe even a bit of a chat to help her decide. But if I started texting back now, I might lose track of time, or worse, be late picking up my kids. I could feel the pressure building—my children’s expectant faces on one side, Linda’s hopeful request on the other. My mind raced, torn between being the reliable mother and the supportive acquaintance, unsure which demand to answer first.
